Abstract

We propose a federated learning framework to handle heterogeneous client devices which do not conform to the population data distribution. The approach hinges upon a parameterized superquantile-based objective, where the parameter ranges over levels of conformity. We present an optimization algorithm and establish its convergence to a stationary point. We show how to practically implement it using secure aggregation by interleaving iterations of the usual federated averaging method with device filtering. We conclude with numerical experiments on neural networks as well as linear models on tasks from computer vision and natural language processing.

1 Introduction

The proliferation of mobile phones, wearables and edge devices has led to an unprecedented growth in the generation of user interaction data. Systems which tap into the power of this rich data while respecting the privacy of users are geared to lead the next generation of intelligent applications and devices. The leading distributed learning framework in this setting is federated learningÂ [30].

In federated learning, a number of client devices with privacy-sensitive data collaboratively learn a machine learning model under the orchestration of a central server, while keeping their data decentralized. This is achieved by pushing the actual computation to the devices while the server coordinates with the devices for aggregation of model updates. Secure aggregation ensures that no individual deviceâ€™s updates are known to either the server or other devicesÂ [7]. Federated learning has found myriad applications ranging from smartphone appsÂ [46] to healthcareÂ [20].

A key feature of federated learning is statistical heterogeneity, i.e., client data distributions are not identically distributed. Each user has unique characteristics which are reflected in the data they generate. These characteristics are influenced by personal, cultural, regional and geographical factors. For instance, the varied use of language contributes to data heterogeneity in a next word prediction task.

Vanilla federated learning and its de facto standard algorithm, FedAvgÂ [30], aim to fit a model to the population distribution of the devices available for training. While this approach works for users who conform to the population (e.g., trend followers), it is liable to fail on individuals who do not conform to the population, leading to poor user experience. The goal of this work is to present a framework to improve the experience of these diversely non-conforming users without sacrificing the good experience of conforming users.

Diversity of users leads to heterogeneity in the loss functions of the users, which in turn manifests itself as heavy tails in the loss distribution over users. Therefore, a natural approach to handling user heterogeneity consists in building an objective based on upper quantiles, in order to focus on the tail distribution. In particular, we use the superquantileÂ [38] of the loss distribution (i.e.,â€„the expectation over its upper tail).

Training with a superquantile-based objective is not straightforward because of its inherent non-smoothness. It is worth emphasizing that any optimization issue can be exacerbated in the federated setting because of the constraints imposed by communication costs and privacy-preserving requirements. Here, we present an algorithm to optimize a superquantile-based objective which overcomes these challenges. It enjoys a time and space complexity which is a constant multiple of the complexity of FedAvg.

Contributions.

We make the following contributions.

  1. (a)

    The Î”Î”\Delta-FL Framework111 pronounced as Simplicial-FL: We introduce the Î”Î”\Delta-FL framework, summarized in FigureÂ 1, to handle heterogeneity of client data distributions. The framework relies on a superquantile-based objective parameterized by the conformity level, which is a scalar summary of how closely a device conforms to the population.

  2. (b)

    Optimization Algorithm: We present an algorithm to optimize the Î”Î”\Delta-FL objective and establish its almost sure convergence to a stationary point. We show how to implement a practical variant of the algorithm with the use of secure aggregation such that it has the same per-iteration communication cost as FedAvg. See FigureÂ 2 for a schematic summary of the algorithm.

  3. (c)

    Numerical Simulations: We demonstrate the breadth of our framework with numerical simulations using neural networks and linear models, on tasks including image classification, language modeling and sentiment analysis based on public datasets. The simulations demonstrate superior performance of Î”Î”\Delta-FL on the upper quantiles of the error on test devices, while being competitive with vanilla federated learning on the mean error. We have released a Python package with scripts to reproduce all simulationsÂ [1].

Outline.

SectionÂ 2 describes the setting and precisely defines conformity. SectionÂ 3 describes the Î”Î”\Delta-FL framework and the training objective. SectionÂ 4 describes a provably convergent algorithm to optimize the Î”Î”\Delta-FL objective, and presents a practical variant of the algorithm. SectionÂ 5 presents numerical simulations of the proposed method. SectionÂ 6 surveys related work. The supplement contains a rigorous presentation of the material with proofs.

2 Problem Setting

Federated learning consists of a number of heterogeneous client devices which collaboratively train a machine learning model. The model is then deployed on all client devices, including those not seen during training. We first review the training setup, followed by test devices.

Test Devices and Conformity.

In this work, we consider â€œtestâ€ devices, unseen during training, whose distribution can be written as a mixture of the training distributions. We define a mixture pÏ€subscriptğ‘ğœ‹p_{\pi} with weight Ï€âˆˆÎ”Nâˆ’1ğœ‹superscriptÎ”ğ‘1\pi\in\Delta^{N-1} as

Definition 1.

The conformity confâ€‹(pÏ€)confsubscriptğ‘ğœ‹\mathrm{conf}(p_{\pi}) of a mixture distribution pÏ€subscriptğ‘ğœ‹p_{\pi} with weight Ï€ğœ‹\pi to the training distribution pÎ±subscriptğ‘ğ›¼p_{\alpha} is defined as minkâˆˆ[N]â¡Î±k/Ï€ksubscriptğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ‘subscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜\min_{k\in[N]}\alpha_{k}/\pi_{k}. The conformity of a client device refers to the conformity of its data distribution.

For every mixture pÏ€subscriptğ‘ğœ‹p_{\pi}, we have that 0<confâ€‹(pÏ€)â‰¤10confsubscriptğ‘ğœ‹10<\mathrm{conf}(p_{\pi})\leq 1. A mixture distribution pÏ€subscriptğ‘ğœ‹p_{\pi} with confâ€‹(pÏ€)=Î¸confsubscriptğ‘ğœ‹ğœƒ\mathrm{conf}(p_{\pi})=\theta must satisfy Ï€kâ‰¤Î±k/Î¸subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜subscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜ğœƒ\pi_{k}\leq\alpha_{k}/\theta for each kğ‘˜k. Since âˆ‘kÏ€k=1subscriptğ‘˜subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜1\sum_{k}\pi_{k}=1, we also get that Ï€kâ‰¥maxâ¡{0,Î±kâˆ’(1âˆ’Î¸)}subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜0subscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜1ğœƒ\pi_{k}\geq\max\{0,\alpha_{k}-(1-\theta)\}. We do not directly impose a lower bound on Ï€ksubscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜\pi_{k} because it is not realistic to assume that the distribution on a test device must necessarily contain a component of every training distribution qksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜q_{k}.

Interpretation.

Assuming that the training devices are a representative sample of the population, every deviceâ€™s distribution can be well-approximated by a mixture pÏ€subscriptğ‘ğœ‹p_{\pi} for some Ï€âˆˆÎ”Nâˆ’1ğœ‹superscriptÎ”ğ‘1\pi\in\Delta^{N-1}. Then, the conformity of a device is a scalar summary of how close it is to the population. A test device with conformity Î¸â‰ˆ1ğœƒ1\theta\approx 1 closely conforms to the population. Then, a model trained on the population pÎ±subscriptğ‘ğ›¼p_{\alpha} can be expected to have a high predictive power, and the user experience on such a device is likely good. In contrast, a test device with conformity Î¸â‰ˆ0ğœƒ0\theta\approx 0 would be vastly different from the population pÎ±subscriptğ‘ğ›¼p_{\alpha}. Here, the predictive power of a model trained on pÎ±subscriptğ‘ğ›¼p_{\alpha} could be arbitrarily poor.

There is a trade-off between the fitting to the population distribution and supporting non-conforming test devices, i.e., those with distribution pÏ€subscriptğ‘ğœ‹p_{\pi} for small confâ€‹(pÏ€)confsubscriptğ‘ğœ‹\mathrm{conf}(p_{\pi}). The conformity level Î¸ğœƒ\theta presents a natural way to encapsulate this tradeoff in a scalar parameter. That is, given a conformity Î¸âˆˆ(0,1)ğœƒ01\theta\in(0,1), we choose to only support test devices with distribution pÏ€subscriptğ‘ğœ‹p_{\pi} satisfying confâ€‹(pÏ€)â‰¥Î¸confsubscriptğ‘ğœ‹ğœƒ\mathrm{conf}(p_{\pi})\geq\theta.

Quantile and Superquantile.

Before proceeding, we recall that the (1âˆ’Î¸)1ğœƒ(1-\theta)-superquantileÂ [38] of a real-valued random variable Xğ‘‹X is defined as

SXâ€‹(Î¸):=infÎ·âˆˆâ„{Î·+1Î¸â€‹ğ”¼â€‹(Xâˆ’Î·)+},assignsubscriptğ‘†ğ‘‹ğœƒsubscriptinfimumğœ‚â„ğœ‚1ğœƒğ”¼subscriptğ‘‹ğœ‚S_{X}(\theta):=\inf_{\eta\in\mathbb{R}}\left\{\eta+\frac{1}{\theta}\,\mathbb{E}(X-\eta)_{+}\right\}\,,

where (Ï)+:=maxâ¡{0,Ï}assignsubscriptğœŒ0ğœŒ(\rho)_{+}:=\max\{0,\rho\}. The right hand side is minimized by the corresponding quantile Î·â‹†=QXâ€‹(Î¸)superscriptğœ‚â‹†subscriptğ‘„ğ‘‹ğœƒ\eta^{\star}=Q_{X}(\theta),

The superquantile is, therefore, a measure of the upper tail of Xğ‘‹X.

3 The Î”Î”\Delta-FL Framework

We now present the Î”Î”\Delta-FL framework to (a) maintain good predictive power on high-conformity devices, and, (b) improve the predictive power on low-conformity devices.

The Î”Î”\Delta-FL framework supplies each test device with a model appropriate to its conformity. In particular, given a discretization {Î¸1,â€¦,Î¸r}subscriptğœƒ1â€¦subscriptğœƒğ‘Ÿ\{\theta_{1},\ldots,\theta_{r}\} of (0,1]01(0,1], Î”Î”\Delta-FL maintains rğ‘Ÿr models, one for each level Î¸jsubscriptğœƒğ‘—\theta_{j} of conformity. Owing to privacy restrictions, the local data is not allowed to leave a device, and hence, the conformity of a test device cannot be measured. Instead, we allow each test device to tune their conformity.

In order to train a model for a given level Î¸ğœƒ\theta of conformity, we aim to do well on all mixtures pÏ€subscriptğ‘ğœ‹p_{\pi} with confâ€‹(pÏ€)â‰¥Î¸confsubscriptğ‘ğœ‹ğœƒ\mathrm{conf}(p_{\pi})\geq\theta. Therefore, we consider the optimization problem

where ğ’«Î¸:={Ï€:confâ€‹(pÏ€)â‰¥Î¸}assignsubscriptğ’«ğœƒconditional-setğœ‹confsubscriptğ‘ğœ‹ğœƒ\mathcal{P}_{\theta}:=\{\pi\,:\,\mathrm{conf}(p_{\pi})\geq\theta\}. Equivalently, we have,

Illustration.

We now illustrate the objective on a simple example of a mixture of Gaussians. Consider a mixture of N=3ğ‘3N=3 Gaussian distributions in â„2superscriptâ„2\mathbb{R}^{2}, with uniform weights (Î±k=1/Nsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜1ğ‘\alpha_{k}=1/N), identity covariance and respective means Î¼1,Î¼2,Î¼3subscriptğœ‡1subscriptğœ‡2subscriptğœ‡3\mu_{1},\mu_{2},\mu_{3} which form a scalene triangle â€“ see FigureÂ 3. Consider the task of mean estimation where fâ€‹(w;Î¾)=â€–Î¾âˆ’wâ€–2ğ‘“ğ‘¤ğœ‰superscriptnormğœ‰ğ‘¤2f(w;\xi)=\|\xi-w\|^{2} so that Fâ€‹(w;p)ğ¹ğ‘¤ğ‘F(w;p) is minimized by the mean of pğ‘p. Now consider a conformity level of Î¸=2/3ğœƒ23\theta=2/3. In the example of FigureÂ 3, this is w2/3=(Î¼1+Î¼3)/2subscriptğ‘¤23subscriptğœ‡1subscriptğœ‡32w_{2/3}=(\mu_{1}+\mu_{3})/2.

Next, consider the set ğ’«2/3subscriptğ’«23\mathcal{P}_{2/3} of all mixture weights Ï€ğœ‹\pi such that confâ€‹(pÏ€)â‰¥2/3confsubscriptğ‘ğœ‹23\mathrm{conf}(p_{\pi})\geq 2/3. In practical terms, Î”Î”\Delta-FL presents an improvement on devices with the worst user experience. Moreover, by optimizing the superquantile, Î”Î”\Delta-FL aims for good performance on all test devices with a given conformity, irrespective of their distribution. Note that while we use a uniform distribution in the illustration of FigureÂ 3 (right), this distribution is unknown in practice.

Proposition 4.

The proof is given in AppendixÂ B. The proofs of partsÂ (a), (c) andÂ (d) are elementary, while partÂ (b) is more technical.

Practical Implementation.

To obtain a practical algorithm, we modify, without proof, AlgorithmÂ 1 to respect system-level constraints of federated learning at scale.

Firstly, we estimate the Î·ğœ‚\eta-step of AlgorithmÂ 1 from a sample of devices. This is because devices are unavailable when offline, and device availability typically follows a diurnal pattern. Difficulties caused by the bias of quantile estimators makes the analysis of this scheme beyond this work.

Secondly, we execute the wğ‘¤w-step as a single round of FedAvg. Communication is often the bottleneck in the federated setting, while local computation is relatively cheap. This heuristic allows us to make more progress at a lower communication cost than strictly following PropositionÂ 4, i.e, solving the wğ‘¤w-step with decreasing suboptimality.

Lastly, we perform the Î·ğœ‚\eta-step and the wğ‘¤w-step using the same sample of devices. With these modifications in place, the resulting algorithm is given in AlgorithmÂ 2. As illustrated in FigureÂ 2, AlgorithmÂ 2 may be viewed as an augmentation of FedAvg with an additional step of filtering devices (LineÂ 8). In particular, the aggregation of model parameters can be performed using secure aggregation.

As secure aggregation dominates the running time in the federated setting due to its expensive communication, AlgorithmÂ 2 has the same per-iteration complexity as FedAvg.

Privacy.

AlgorithmÂ 2 reveals neither the data nor the model parameters of the client devices, the latter via the use of secure aggregation. However, the algorithm, as it is currently stated, requires each selected client devices to reveal its loss (a scalar) on the current model to the server. AppendixÂ B.1 presents a variant of AlgorithmÂ 2 which ensures the same privacy-preservation of FedAvg at the cost of extra communication. This is achieved by implementing the quantile calculation using multiple secure aggregation calls.

5 Numerical Simulations

We now experimentally compare the performance of Î”Î”\Delta-FL with FedAvg. The simulations were implemented in Python using automatic differentiation provided by PyTorch, while the data was preprocessed using LEAFÂ [8]. Full details of the simulations are given in AppendixÂ C. A software package implementing the proposed algorithm and scripts to reproduce experimental results can be found inÂ [1].

Datasets, Tasks and Models.

We consider three tasks, whose datasets and numbers of train and test devices are described in TableÂ 1. We weigh training device kğ‘˜k by the number of datapoints on the device. All models were trained with the (multinomial, if applicable) logistic loss and evaluated with the misclassification error.

  1. (a)

    Character Recognition: We use the EMNIST datasetÂ [11], where the input xğ‘¥x is a 28Ã—28282828\times 28 grayscale image of a handwritten character and the output yğ‘¦y is its identification (0-9, a-z, A-Z). Each device is a writer of the character xğ‘¥x. We use a linear model and a convolutional neural network (ConvNet).

  2. (b)

    Sentiment Analysis: We learn a binary classifier over the Sent140 datasetÂ [16] where the input xğ‘¥x is a Twitter post and the output y=Â±1ğ‘¦plus-or-minus1y=\pm 1 is its sentiment. Each device corresponds to a distinct Twitter user. The linear model is built on the average of the GloVe embeddingsÂ [34] of the words of the post, while the non-convex model is a Long Short Term Memory modelÂ [19] built on the GloVe embeddings. We refer to the latter as â€œRNNâ€.

  3. (c)

    Character-Level Language Modeling: We learn a character-level language model over the Complete Works of Shakespeare [43], formulated as a multiclass classification problem, where the input xğ‘¥x is a window of 20 characters, the output yğ‘¦y is the next (i.e., 21st) character. Each device is a role from a play (e.g., Brutus from The Tragedy of Julius Caesar). The model is a Gated Recurrent UnitÂ [9], which we refer to as â€œRNNâ€.

Hyperparameters and Evaluation Metrics.

Hyperparameters of FedAvg were chosen similar to the defaults ofÂ [30]. We fixed an iteration budget for each dataset and tuned a learning rate schedule using grid search to find the best terminal loss averaged over training devices for FedAvg. The same values were used on all Î”Î”\Delta-FL runs without further tuning. In addition, the linear models also use a â„“22superscriptsubscriptâ„“22\ell_{2}^{2} regularization, which was tuned separately for FedAvg and each value of Î¸ğœƒ\theta for Î”Î”\Delta-FL. The regularization parameter was selected to minimize the 909090th percentile of the misclassification error on a held-out subset of training devices. Each Î”Î”\Delta-FL experiment was repeated for conformity levels Î¸=0.8,0.5,0.1ğœƒ0.80.50.1\theta=0.8,0.5,0.1. Recall that we cannot actually measure the conformity of a test device due to privacy restrictions.

We track the loss Fâ€‹(â‹…;qk)ğ¹â‹…subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜F(\cdot\,;q_{k}) incurred on each training device and the misclassification error on each test device. We summarize these distributions with their mean and the 909090th percentile. We use the latter to gauge performance on devices with low conformity. Other percentiles of these distributions, and more simulation results are presented in AppendixÂ C. We report each metric averaged over 5 different random seeds.

Experimental Results.

TableÂ 2 lists the 909090th percentile of the misclassification error on the test devices on the final model at the end of our iteration budget. We observe that for all datasets, the 909090th percentile of the test error is smaller for Î”Î”\Delta-FL than for FedAvg at some value of Î¸ğœƒ\theta, and often at multiple values of Î¸ğœƒ\theta. This highlights the benefit of the Î”Î”\Delta-FL framework in dealing with heterogeneous device distributions. TableÂ 3 records the mean of the distribution of test errors. We see that Î”Î”\Delta-FL is on par with FedAvg on the mean of the misclassification errors on the test devices, and sometimes even better.

Performance Across Devices.

We now visualize the misclassification error across all test devices in a histogram in FigureÂ 4. We note that Î”Î”\Delta-FL exhibits thinner upper tails on the error, which shows an improved performance on devices which do not conform with the population.

Next, FigureÂ 5 shows a scatter plot of the loss (resp. error) and the number of datapoints on a training (resp. testing) device. Observe, firstly, that Î”Î”\Delta-FL reduces the variance of of the loss on the train devices. Secondly, note that amongst test devices with a small number of data points (e.g., <200absent200<200 for EMNIST or <100absent100<100 for Sent140), Î”Î”\Delta-FL reduces the variance of the misclassification error. Both effects are more pronounced on the neural network models.

Both these plots are indicative of an improved user experience of Î”Î”\Delta-FL on devices which do not conform as well as devices with little data.

Performance Across Iterations.

FigureÂ 6 compares the convergence of AlgorithmÂ 2 with FedAvg, measured in terms of the number of secure aggregation calls. We see that Î”Î”\Delta-FL is competitive with FedAvg in convergence rate, despite using the same hyperparameters which were tuned for FedAvg.

6 Related Work

Federated learning was introduced byÂ McMahan etÂ al. [30] as a distributed learning approach to handle on-device machine learning, with several recent extensionsÂ [24, 7, 44, 41, 42, 36] â€“ seeÂ [23] for a survey. We address non-conformity of heterogeneous client devices, which is broadly applicable in these settings.

The classical field of distributed optimizationÂ [6] has seen a recent surge of interest with frameworks suited to synchronous centralizedÂ [45, 29], decentralizedÂ [17] and asynchronous settingsÂ [26]. Past worksÂ [12, 14] have considered model plurality (i.e., an ensemble of global models) in the context of distributed learning.

Robust optimizationÂ [5], which espouses hedging against uncertainty by taking a worst-case approach, has become popular in machine learningÂ [27, 13, 25]. This approach is closely related to the risk measure approach studied in economics and financeÂ [2, 38, 4] . The work we present here considers a novel use of the superquantile, a popular risk measure, in handling device heterogeneity in federated learning with a focus on engineering plausibility.

Past works which considered the use of superquantiles in a centralized setting often used linear programming or convex programming approaches including interior point algorithmsÂ [40, 37]. In this work, we present a convergent inexact alternate minimization algorithm and show how to practically implement in the case of federated learning.

The paper [31] gave generalization bounds on test distributions which can be expressed as a mixture of training distributions. The technical tools used to address fairness in federated learning inÂ [31, 28] bear a resemblance to ones used here, albeit to address different problems. This connection could however potentially be leveraged to obtain statistical results for our approach. We focus in this paper on the practical optimization aspects of our approach. The orthogonal question of personalization of federated learning modelsÂ [e.g. 22] is also an interesting avenue for future work.

7 Conclusions

We present a federated learning framework to train models better suited to heterogeneity of client data distributions in general, and non-conforming users in particular. This is achieved by minimizing a parameterized superquantile-based objective with the parameter ranging over conformity levels of the clients. We study an optimization algorithm to minimize this objective and present a practical variant adapted to the engineering constraints of federated learning. We present compelling numerical evidence in support of the proposed framework on linear models and neural networks for various real-world tasks.

Appendix A Problem Setup and Framework

Suppose we have Nğ‘N client devices which aim to collaboratively train a machine learning model. We measure the loss of a model wâˆˆâ„dğ‘¤superscriptâ„ğ‘‘w\in\mathbb{R}^{d} on a device with data distribution qğ‘q by

Example.

In the supervised machine learning setting, each Î¾âˆˆğ’µğœ‰ğ’µ\xi\in\mathcal{Z} is an input-output pair Î¾=(x,y)ğœ‰ğ‘¥ğ‘¦\xi=(x,y). The function fğ‘“f is of the form â„“â€‹(y,Ï†â€‹(x;w))â„“ğ‘¦ğœ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¤\ell(y,\varphi(x;w)), where Ï†â€‹(x;w)ğœ‘ğ‘¥ğ‘¤\varphi(x;w) makes a prediction on input xğ‘¥x under model wğ‘¤w using, for example, a neural network, and â„“â„“\ell is a loss function such as the square loss â„“â€‹(y,yâ€²)=(yâˆ’yâ€²)2/2â„“ğ‘¦superscriptğ‘¦â€²superscriptğ‘¦superscriptğ‘¦â€²22\ell(y,y^{\prime})=(y-y^{\prime})^{2}/2.

Test Devices.

At evaluation time, we get a novel device whose data distribution pâ€²superscriptğ‘â€²p^{\prime} is, owing to heterogeneity of devices, distinct from the training distribution pÎ±subscriptğ‘ğ›¼p_{\alpha}, which we can write as

pÎ±=âˆ‘k=1NÎ±kâ€‹qk.subscriptğ‘ğ›¼superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘subscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{\alpha}=\sum_{k=1}^{N}\alpha_{k}\,q_{k}\,.

In this work, we investigate methods which perform well not only on average, but also on all devices whose data distribution pâ€²superscriptğ‘â€²p^{\prime} is close to the training distribution pÎ±subscriptğ‘ğ›¼p_{\alpha}. We shall make this precise in the sequel.

It is known that the standard machine learning technique of minimizing Fâ€‹(â‹…;pÎ±)ğ¹â‹…subscriptğ‘ğ›¼F(\cdot\,;p_{\alpha}) can lead to bad performance on the test device, even when pâ€²superscriptğ‘â€²p^{\prime} is a small perturbation of the training distribution pÎ±subscriptğ‘ğ›¼p_{\alpha}.

Approach.

In this work, we focus on test devices whose distribution can be written as a convex combination of the distributions from training devices with weights close to the true training weights Î±ksubscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜\alpha_{k}. Concretely, given a conformity level 0<Î¸<10ğœƒ10<\theta<1, we define the set ğ’«Î¸subscriptğ’«ğœƒ\mathcal{P}_{\theta} of permissible weights as

ğ’«Î¸={Ï€âˆˆÎ”Nâˆ’1:Ï€kâ‰¤Î±kÎ¸â€‹âˆ€kâˆˆ[N]}.subscriptğ’«ğœƒconditional-setğœ‹superscriptÎ”ğ‘1subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜subscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜ğœƒfor-allğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ‘\mathcal{P}_{\theta}=\left\{\pi\in\Delta^{N-1}\,:\,\pi_{k}\leq\frac{\alpha_{k}}{\theta}\,\forall\,k\in[N]\right\}\,.

We now consider distributions of the form

pÏ€=âˆ‘k=1NÏ€kâ€‹qk,subscriptğ‘ğœ‹superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜1ğ‘subscriptğœ‹ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘ğ‘˜p_{\pi}=\sum_{k=1}^{N}\pi_{k}q_{k}\,,

where Ï€âˆˆğ’«Î¸ğœ‹subscriptğ’«ğœƒ\pi\in\mathcal{P}_{\theta}. Note that Î±=(Î±1,â‹¯,Î±N)âˆˆğ’«Î¸ğ›¼subscriptğ›¼1â‹¯subscriptğ›¼ğ‘subscriptğ’«ğœƒ\alpha=(\alpha_{1},\cdots,\alpha_{N})\in\mathcal{P}_{\theta} for every Î¸âˆˆ(0,1)ğœƒ01\theta\in(0,1).

The training approach pursued here consists in minimizing

FÎ¸â€‹(w):=maxÏ€âˆˆğ’«Î¸â¡Fâ€‹(w;pÏ€).assignsubscriptğ¹ğœƒğ‘¤subscriptğœ‹subscriptğ’«ğœƒğ¹ğ‘¤subscriptğ‘ğœ‹\displaystyle F_{\theta}(w):=\max_{\pi\in\mathcal{P}_{\theta}}F(w;p_{\pi})\,. (8)

There is a trade-off between the size of ğ’«Î¸subscriptğ’«ğœƒ\mathcal{P}_{\theta} and the performance minwâ¡Fâ€‹(w;pÎ±)subscriptğ‘¤ğ¹ğ‘¤subscriptğ‘ğ›¼\min_{w}F(w;p_{\alpha}) on the training distribution pÎ±subscriptğ‘ğ›¼p_{\alpha}. A small conformity Î¸ğœƒ\theta implies that we take a more conservative approach where we would like to be able to make guarantees on test distributions pÏ€subscriptğ‘ğœ‹p_{\pi} which do not conform much with the training distribution pÎ±subscriptğ‘ğ›¼p_{\alpha}. However, this may come at the cost of fitting the training distribution pÎ±subscriptğ‘ğ›¼p_{\alpha}.

B.1 Quantile Computation with Secure Aggregation

Recall from the SectionÂ 4 that AlgorithmÂ 2, as stated, requires each selected client device to send its loss to the server for the client filtering step. We now present a way to perform this step without any reduction in privacy from directly sending client losses to the server. This can be achieved by implementing the quantile computation using secure aggregation. This section is based on [36], who show how to compute the geometric median using secure aggregation.

Setup.

Suppose we wish to find the Ï„ğœ\tau-quantile of x1,â‹¯,xmâˆˆâ„subscriptğ‘¥1â‹¯subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘šâ„x_{1},\cdots,x_{m}\in\mathbb{R} with respective weights Î±1,â‹¯,Î±m>0subscriptğ›¼1â‹¯subscriptğ›¼ğ‘š0\alpha_{1},\cdots,\alpha_{m}>0. Recall that Î¼Ï„subscriptğœ‡ğœ\mu_{\tau} is the Ï„ğœ\tau quantile if

âˆ‘k:xkâ‰¤Î¼Ï„Î±kâ‰¥Ï„,and,â€‹âˆ‘k:xkâ‰¥Î¼Ï„Î±kâ‰¥1âˆ’Ï„.formulae-sequencesubscript:ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğœ‡ğœsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜ğœand,subscript:ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘˜subscriptğœ‡ğœsubscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜1ğœ\sum_{k\,:\,x_{k}\leq\mu_{\tau}}\alpha_{k}\geq\tau\,,\quad\text{and,}\quad\sum_{k\,:\,x_{k}\geq\mu_{\tau}}\alpha_{k}\geq 1-\tau\,.

It is knownÂ [e.g., 15, Chap. 1, Exercise 3] that Î¼Ï„subscriptğœ‡ğœ\mu_{\tau} is a Ï„ğœ\tau-quantile iff it it minimizes HÏ„:â„â†’â„:subscriptğ»ğœâ†’â„â„H_{\tau}:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R} defined as

Algorithm.

Recall that secure aggregation can find a weighted mean of vectors (and hence, scalars) distributed across mğ‘šm devices without revealing each deviceâ€™s vector to other devices or the server. We now show how to compute a quantile as an iterative weighted mean, making it amenable to implementation via secure aggregation. We note that this might not be the most efficient way of implementing quantile computation in a privacy-preserving manner. This is because secure aggregation was designed for high-dimensional vectors and it might be possible to do much better in the case of scalars. Nevertheless, we present the algorithm as a proof-of-concept. The underlying algorithm, based on the principle of majorization-minimization was used, e.g.,inÂ [21].

We now modify AlgorithmÂ 2 to perform the quantile computation in a privacy-preserving manner. However, the server can no longer perform the client filtering step. Appendix C Experimental Results: Complete Details

We conduct our experiments on three datasets from computer vision and natural language processing. These datasets contain a natural, non-iid split of data which is reflective of data heterogeneity encountered in federated learning. In this section, we describe in details the experimental setup and the results. SectionÂ C.1 described the datasets and tasks. SectionÂ C.2 gives a detailed description of the hyperparameters used and the evaluation methodology. Lastly, SectionÂ C.3 gives the experimental results.

Since each device has a finite number of datapoints in the examples below, we let its probability distribution qksubscriptğ‘ğ‘˜q_{k} to be the empirical distribution over the available examples, and the weight Î±ksubscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜\alpha_{k} to be proportional to the number of datapoints available on the device.

C.1 Datasets and Tasks

We use the three following datasets, described in detail below. The data was preprocessed using the LEAF frameworkÂ [8].

C.1.1 EMNIST for handwritten-letter recognition

Dataset.

EMNISTÂ [11] is a character recognition dataset. This dataset contains images of handwritten digits or letters, labeled with their identification (a-z,A-Z, 0-9). The images are grey-scaled pictures of 28Ã—28=784282878428\times 28=784 pixels.

Train and Test Devices.

Each image is also annotated with the â€œwriterâ€ of the image, i.e., the human subject who hand-wrote the digit/letter during the data collection process. From this set of devices, we discard all devices containing less than 100 images and randomly subsampled half of the remaining devices resulting in 173017301730 total devices. We performed the subsampling for computational tractability. We finally split these 173017301730 devices into a training set of devices and a testing set of devices of equal sizes.

Model.

We consider the following models for this task.

  • â€¢

    Linear Model: We use a linear softmax regression model. In this case each Fksubscriptğ¹ğ‘˜F_{k} is convex. We train parameters wâˆˆâ„62Ã—784ğ‘¤superscriptâ„62784w\in\mathbb{R}^{62\times 784}. Given an input image xâˆˆâ„784ğ‘¥superscriptâ„784x\in\mathbb{R}^{784}, the score of each class câˆˆ[62]ğ‘delimited-[]62c\in[62] is the dot product âŸ¨wc,xâŸ©subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘ğ‘¥\langle w_{c},x\rangle. The probability pcsubscriptğ‘ğ‘p_{c} assigned to each class is then computed as a softmax: pc=expâ¡âŸ¨wc,xâŸ©/âˆ‘câ€²expâ¡âŸ¨wcâ€²,xâŸ©subscriptğ‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘¤ğ‘ğ‘¥subscriptsuperscriptğ‘â€²subscriptğ‘¤superscriptğ‘â€²ğ‘¥p_{c}=\exp{\langle w_{c},x\rangle}/\sum_{c^{\prime}}\exp{\langle w_{c^{\prime}},x\rangle}. The prediction for a given image is then the class with the highest probability.

  • â€¢

    ConvNet: We also consider a convolutional neural network. Its architecture satisfies the following scheme:

    Input 784 âŸ¶âŸ¶ Input 784 absent\displaystyle\parbox{30.0pt}{\centering Input \\ \small{784}\@add@centering}\longrightarrow Conv 2D filter = 32 kernel = Ã—55 âŸ¶ReLUâŸ¶ Max Pool kernel = Ã—22 stride = 2 âŸ¶ Conv 2D filter = 64 kernel = Ã—55 \displaystyle\parbox{70.0pt}{\centering Conv 2D \\ \small{filter = 32} \\ \small{kernel = $5\times 5$}\@add@centering}\longrightarrow\;\;\;\;\parbox{30.0pt}{ReLU}\;\;\longrightarrow\parbox{76.0pt}{\centering Max Pool \\ \small{kernel = $2\times 2$} \\ \small{stride = $2$}\@add@centering}\longrightarrow\parbox{76.0pt}{\centering Conv 2D \\ \small{filter = 64} \\ \small{kernel = $5\times 5$}\@add@centering}

    In other words, it contains two convolutional layers with max-pooling and one fully connected layer (F.C) of which outputs a vector in â„62superscriptâ„62\mathbb{R}^{62}. The outputs of the ConvNet are scores with respect to each class. They are also used with a softmax operation to compute probabilities.

The loss used to train both models is the multinomial logistic loss Lâ€‹(p,y)=âˆ’logâ¡pyğ¿ğ‘ğ‘¦subscriptğ‘ğ‘¦L(p,y)=-\log p_{y} where pğ‘p denotes the vector of probabilities computed by the model and pysubscriptğ‘ğ‘¦p_{y} denotes its yğ‘¦yth component. In the convex case we add a quadratic regularization term of the form (Î»/2)â€‹â€–wâ€–22ğœ†2superscriptsubscriptnormğ‘¤22({\lambda}/{2})\|w\|_{2}^{2}.

C.1.2 Sent140 for Sentiment Analysis

Dataset.

Sent140Â [16] is a text dataset of 1,600,498 tweets produced by 660,120 Twitter accounts. Each tweet is represented by a character string with emojis redacted. Each tweet is labeled with a binary sentiment reaction (i.e., positive or negative), which is inferred based on the emojis in the original tweet.

Train and Test Devices.

Each device represents a twitter account and contains only tweets published by this account. From this set of devices we discarded all devices containing less that 50 tweets, and split the 877 remaining devices rest of devices into a train set and a test set of sizes 438438438 and 439439439 respectively. This split was held fixed for all experiments. Each word in the tweet is encoded by its 505050-dimensional GloVe embeddingÂ [34].

Model.

We consider the following models.

  • â€¢

    Linear Model: We consider a l2subscriptğ‘™2l_{2}-regularized linear logistic regression model where the parameter vector wğ‘¤w is of dimension 505050. In this case, each Fksubscriptğ¹ğ‘˜F_{k} is convex. We summarize each tweet by the average of the GloVe embeddings of the words of the tweet.

  • â€¢

    RNN: The nonconvex model is a Long Short Term Memory (LSTM) modelÂ [19] built on the GloVe embeddings of the words of the tweet. The hidden dimension of the LSTM is same as the embedding dimension, i.e., 505050. We refer to it as â€œRNNâ€.

The loss function is the binary logistic loss.

C.1.3 Shakespeare for Language Modeling

Dataset.

The dataset consists of text from the Complete Works of William Shakespeare as raw text. We formulate the task as a multi-class classification problem with 53 classes (a-z, A-Z, other) as follows. At each point, we consider the previous H=20ğ»20H=20 characters, and build xâˆˆ{0,1}HÃ—53ğ‘¥superscript01ğ»53x\in\{0,1\}^{H\times 53} as a one-hot encoding of these Hğ»H characters. The goal is then to predict the next character, which can belong to 53 classes.

Train and Test Devices.

Each device corresponds to a role in a given play (e.g., Brutus from The Tragedy of Julius Caesar). All devices with less than 100 total examples are discarded, and the remaining devices are split into 544544544 training and 545545545 testing devices.

Models.

We use a Gated Recurrent Unit (GRU) modelÂ [9] with 128128128 hidden units for this purpose. We refer to it as â€œRNNâ€ in the plots. This is followed by a fully connected layer with 53 outputs, the output of which is used as the score for each character. As in the case of image recognition, probabilities are obtained using the softmax operation. We use the multinomial logistic loss.

C.2 Algorithms, Hyperparameters and Evaluation strategy

C.2.1 Algorithms

We compare FedAvgÂ [30] with the proposed algorithm, given in Algorithm 2 on the datasets presented in SectionÂ C.1. We run Algorithm 2 with different conformity levels Î¸ğœƒ\theta for Î¸âˆˆ{0.8,0.5,0.1}ğœƒ0.80.50.1\theta\in\{0.8,0.5,0.1\}.

C.2.2 Hyperparameters

Rounds.

We measure the progress of each algorithm by the number of calls to secure aggregation, i.e., the number of communication rounds. Both FedAvg and AlgorithmÂ 2 require one call to secure aggregation per iteration, hence the number of communication rounds is also equivalently the number of iterations of each algorithm.

For the experiments, we choose the number of communication rounds depending on the convergence of the optimization and a budget on wall-clock time. For the EMNIST dataset, we run the algorithm for 300030003000 communication rounds with the linear model and 100010001000 for the ConvNet. For the Sent140 dataset, we run the 100010001000 communication rounds for the linear model and 600600600 for the RNN. For the Shakespeare dataset, we run 600600600 communication rounds.

Devices per Round.

We chose the number of devices per round similar to the baselines of [30]. All devices are assumed to be available and selections are made uniformly at random. In particular, we select 100100100 devices per round for all experiments with the exception of Sent140 RNN for which we used 505050 devices per round.

LocalUpdate and Minibatch Size.

Each selected device (which is not un-selected, in case of AlgorithmÂ 2) locally runs 111 epoch of mini-batch stochastic gradient descent in the LocalUpdate method. We used the default mini-batch of 101010 for all experimentsÂ [30], except for 161616 for EMNIST ConvNet and Shakespeare. This is because the latter experiments were run using on a GPU, as we describe in the section on the hardware.

Learning rate scheme.

We now describe the learning rate Î³tsubscriptğ›¾ğ‘¡\gamma_{t} used during LocalUpdate. For the linear model we used a constant fixed learning rate Î³tâ‰¡Î³0subscriptğ›¾ğ‘¡subscriptğ›¾0\gamma_{t}\equiv\gamma_{0}, while for the neural network models, we using a step decay scheme of the learning rate Î³t=Î³0â€‹câˆ’âŒŠt/t0âŒ‹subscriptğ›¾ğ‘¡subscriptğ›¾0superscriptğ‘ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¡0\gamma_{t}=\gamma_{0}c^{-\lfloor t/t_{0}\rfloor} for some where Î³0subscriptğ›¾0\gamma_{0} and 0<câ‰¤10ğ‘10<c\leq 1 are tuned. We tuned the learning rates only for the baseline FedAvg and used the same learning rate for Î”Î”\Delta-FL at all values of Î¸ğœƒ\theta.

For the neural network models, we fixed t0subscriptğ‘¡0t_{0} so that the learning rate was decayed once or twice during the fixed time horizon Tğ‘‡T. In particular, we used t0=400subscriptğ‘¡0400t_{0}=400 for EMNIST ConvNet (where T=1000ğ‘‡1000T=1000), t0=200subscriptğ‘¡0200t_{0}=200 for Sent140 RNN (where T=600ğ‘‡600T=600) and t0=200subscriptğ‘¡0200t_{0}=200 for Shakespeare (where T=600ğ‘‡600T=600). We tuned cğ‘c from the set {2âˆ’3,2âˆ’2,2âˆ’1,1}superscript23superscript22superscript211\{2^{-3},2^{-2},2^{-1},1\}, while the choice of the range of Î³0subscriptğ›¾0\gamma_{0} depended on the dataset-model pair. The tuning criterion we used was the mean of the loss distribution over the training devices (with device kğ‘˜k weighted by Î±ksubscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜\alpha_{k}) at the end of the time horizon. That is, we chose the Î³0,csubscriptğ›¾0ğ‘\gamma_{0},c which gave the best terminal training loss.

Tuning of the regularization parameter.

The regularization parameter Î»ğœ†\lambda for linear models was tuned with cross validation from the set {10âˆ’k:kâˆˆ{3,â‹¯,8}}conditional-setsuperscript10ğ‘˜ğ‘˜3â‹¯8\{10^{-k}\,:\,k\in\{3,\cdots,8\}\}. This was performed as described below.

For each dataset, we held out half the training devices as validation devices. Then, for different values of the regularization parameter, we trained a model with the (smaller subset of) training devices and evaluate its performance on the validation devices. We selected the value of the regularization parameter as the one which gave the smallest 101010th percentile of the misclassification error on the validation devices.

C.2.3 Evaluation Strategy and Other Details

Evaluation metrics.

We record the loss of each training device and the misclassification error of each testing device, as measured on its local data.

The evaluation metrics noted in SectionÂ C.3 are the following : the weighted mean of the loss distribution over the training devices, the (unweighted) mean misclassification error over the testing devices, the weighted Ï„ğœ\tau-percentile of the loss over the training device and the (unweighted) Ï„ğœ\tau-percentile of the misclassification error over the testing devices for values of Ï„ğœ\tau among {20,50,60,80,90,95}205060809095\{20,50,60,80,90,95\}. The weight used for training device kğ‘˜k is Î±ksubscriptğ›¼ğ‘˜\alpha_{k}, which was set proportional to the number of datapoints on the device.

Evaluation times.

We evaluate the model during training process for once every lğ‘™l rounds. The value of lğ‘™l used was l=50ğ‘™50l=50 for EMNIST linear model, l=10ğ‘™10l=10 for EMNIST ConvNet and Shakespeare, l=20ğ‘™20l=20 for Sent140 linear model and l=25ğ‘™25l=25 for Sent140 RNN.

Hardware.

We run each experiment as a simulation as a single process. The linear models were trained on m5.8xlarge AWS instances, each with an Intel Xeon Platinum 8000 series processor with 128128128 GB of memory running at most 3.13.13.1 GHz. The neural network experiments were trained on workstation with an Intel i9 processor with 128128128 GB of memory at 1.21.21.2 GHz, and two Nvidia Titan Xp GPUs. The Sent140 RNN experiments were run on a CPU while the other neural network experiments were run using GPUs.

Software Packages.

Our implementation is based on NumPy using the Python language. In the neural network experiments, we use PyTorch to implement the LocalUpdate procedure, i.e., the model itself and the automatic differentiation routines provided by PyTorch to make SGD updates.

Randomness.

Since several sampling routines appear in the procedures such as the selection of devices or the local stochastic gradient, we carry our experiments with five different seeds and plot the average metric value over these seeds. Each simulation is run on a single process. Where appropriate, we report one standard deviation from the mean.
